2015/2016 vintage, had in 2017. Hazy, dirtied orange, tiny bit of off-white foam. Nose has rustic white wine funk, fermenting "pulpy" orchard fruit, like plums, sure, but it makes me think of ripe cherry plums rather than that. Chinese plum, faint yellow cherries, oaky vanilla, mold, salt, green hay. The funk takes center stage in the taste, with a sharp sourness, like lemon juice, with mild vinegary notes. Dirty barrel, white wine gone bad, mixed crunchy herbs, the regular lambic funk, but with a really nice twist in the end. A nice fruity, juicy undertone, that makes me think of Chinese plum and some nice grapefruit flesh, too. Aftertaste is pretty dry, but has lingering oak stave and sour funk. Medium to light body, spritzy carbonation. Great lambic with subtle notes from the added plums, but they¬íre somewhat special. Not bringing a lot in the mix, but the lambic¬ís already pretty complex as it is. Great!

I very much liked this one.

Aroma - wild potent yeast, wheat, and farms funk.

Taste - is sour, there is plenty of funk, and sweaty farmhouse nature. The fruit is difficult to discern. There is that wild yeast potency, that offers a unique sort of power that almost defies description. There is a little woody note as well.

Mouthfeel/body is light/medium, it¬ís easy to drink with a low/moderate amount of carbonation. Bottle. Murky brown body with small white head. Aroma is nice fruity sour with hints of vinegar and plums. Taste is more plums with nice sour grains and hints of wood. Aftertaste is dry and sour.
375ml bottle pours out a peach color topped with a white head. Nose is nice sour tartness some fruit a nice funky barrel. Taste is more of fruit big pucker light bugs. This is very good.

Bottle. Pours a red-orange, almost pinkish color with a small white head. Wonderfull sweet and fruity aroma with notes of syrup, berry seeds, plum and roses. Taste is tart and fruity and ends with a fruity bitterness (like a grapefruit) and a certain dryness. Low carbonation, soft mouthfeel.

Bottle. Pours hazy red/orange/pink with small white head. Aroma is sweet and lovely with notes of plums and flowers. Taste is tart but with a really nice and fruity finish. Notes of grapefruit, plums and blossoms.

Scent on the glass is a bit odorous but only to a very mild extent. Manages to be relatively mild considering the residual sugar. Finish is smooth with light dryness. Very approachable. Great.

750 ml bottle. 2014-2015. Yellowish, orange colour. Thin white head. Vinegar, hints of apples, hints of white wine, grassy, hay-like notes in the aroma. Very nice fruity, refreshing beginning. Rather acidic than sour in the middle. Citrussy, dry finish. Lovely, fruity palate. Sharp, bubbly, thick texture. Rather light bodied, really enjoyable fruit lambic.

375 bottle (dated 2015/2016) from one of the Steve¬ís liquor stores in Madison, WI, served a little below cellar temp in a New Glarus flute. Small-to-moderate off-white head dies quickly above the lightly bubbly, cloudy pale amber body...nose of horse blanket, dogwood, light yeast, and, as it warms more, sweet-tart plums; it¬ís quite pleasant and initially sharp but after a few minutes it has weakened too much and doesn¬ít come off as all that expressive....flavor is faintly sweet and quite tart at the front, growing strongly sour and very dry at the finish, strongly acidic, and peppery-sharp on the end-palate...full-bodied, lively carbonation despite the minimal head and no pop to the cork...while this is pretty tart and stinging at the finish I suspect some of that actually comes from the bitterness in the plum skins, or perhaps from hops, as the brett character is relatively mild. It¬ís a nice enough beer but I was hoping for more I guess - not often I get to have a "new" lambic around here - and I¬íll have to try to find an older bottle, or hang onto another of this vintage for a year or two and see how it progresses.

Bottle at Stadin Panimo. Hazy orange color, white head. Sour taste with citrus, wheat, tart, oak, earthy notes, acidic notes and grass. Sour finish with citrus, wheat, earthy notes, acidic notes, toast, tart and grass. Excellent lambic.

Rating #1899 - 2015.09.22 - Bottle is (2013). Pours a purply red a bubbly white cap. Aroma is plum, ripened pear, currant. Palate is more of this soft fruit sweetness, nice tartness - a well achieved fruit sour that begs attention to detail. Girlfriend approved.

This beer has had a very  long journey to finally be consumed by me. Mcberko gifted this 375mL c&c bottle to me a little while ago as a thank you for letting him crash at my house. I told him it wasn¬ít a big deal and I didn¬ít need beer in return but he was very giving.Thank you, Matt.  I had previously drank this beer but wouldn¬ít splurge on another bottle to rate. Even Andrew from Seattle wanted me to rate this beer. Another overly kind RBian. That¬ís how it got into my hands but the journey was much longer. 
Taking a step back, this beer was a blend of 4 different breweries from Belgium that were all sent to Tilquin. After some months it was placed on a ship and made a voyage to, my guess, the east coast of Canada. Afterward, it made it or all the way to Vancouver, BC where Matt purchased it. To pay his way onto the underground RB railroad, he smuggled - under the cover of night I assume and facing potential treason charges - this bottle across the border and brought it to the Emerald City. You would think the journey ends there but that is just the beginning.
I had all intentions of drinking it in Seattle but just couldn¬ít get to it. Even at the last tasting, the day before I moved out, this was sitting in the fridge. Yet, it could not be consumed. So, this beer started on a cross country moving trip. Funny enough i was joined by the DIPA rating machine himself,  mcberko. He joined me on the trip until we reached SLC, Utah. Now when you travel with a real life ticker, or dink rater as they are known in Canadia, there is little time for anything but new beer. In Denver I saw notalush but we meet up at a brewery. I gave him Logsdon and a brett beer from Red Rock. Through the Midwest I had too many new beers I wanted to drink, particularly in Kansas and Missouri where I had to catch up on my old rating-grounds. Even saw csbosox but he isn¬ít active and was drinking wine as I was sample Free State beers in the Olathe Whole Foods. Apparently, there is a new WF in the KC area, which I didn¬ít know and accidentally went to the wrong place. Gave him a Blvd Saison brett crowler, apparently I gift brett beer only. Made it to Cincinnati and even saw Pruf and his family for about 90 min. But wanted to share beer he hasn¬ít had yet. He on the other hand shared 1 good beer and 3 shitty ones. Next stop is Morgantown, WV. As any RBIian will tell you, when you get a chance to tick WV beer you don¬ít take it for granted. And now I¬ím a finally at my new home in Maryland drinking this beer. 
It seems i live in a bit of a craft beer desert. The liquor stores close at 9 pm and don¬ít have too much craft anyway and definitely don¬ít have singles. I¬íve amassed a decent amount of beers throughout the trip but most are earmarked for something. So, here I am, sitting naked in my new big tub, eating fruit salad that was given to us by our new neighbors, and finally drinking this beer. What a journey it has been and how many wonderful people I got to see on it. (And I didn¬ít even get to mention all the wonderful people that aren¬ít RBians like Rach of mcberko fame, Joe in Denver, Christina and Jean in KC, in-laws in StL, Lora in Cincy, minus Bill, and my wonderful and patient wife Abbey who gave birth to a beautiful 2-month old darling named Lorenna).

From bottle. Pours hazy apricot golden with a white head. Aroma of funk, barnyard, fruity, juicy, apricot, light plums. Taste is the same, super sour, juicy, lots of funk. Lovely!

Bottle from Drankcentrale Rotsaert, Zedelgem. A simply marvellous beer. Tangy sourness, beautifully complimented, underscored and boosted by a light pulpy fruit sweet tang. Beautiful balance. Magnificent stuff. Enjoyed in a threefold tribute - firstly for my son¬ís birthday, secondly to toast a sensational victory by LCFC over Liverpool (complete with Jamie Vardy wonderstrike) and thirdly to mark the passing of Jon Bunch, the lead singer of Sense Field. Jon was a great musician and a great man.

Oh Lord, this is something! Its sourness in aroma and taste is just pure beautiful. Mouthfeel makes you take another and another sip. Don¬ít want to stop to drink this beer. And the tiny fruity touch in the end is almost magical. Love this beer.

375 mL bottle from Conn Ave Wine & Spirits in DC. Pours a murky orange gumwood color with minimal bubbly white head. Nose holds balanced plum and vinous fruit tones mixing with an earthy, lightly lemony funk. The palate is much more complex, with gorgeous plum, prune, unripe peach, tannic acidity, light citric tang and basement funk. Palate is captivating; definitely not nearly as aggressive as most fresh Cantillon fruit lambics, with a finish that is soft, almost caressing, though still acidic. The middle of the mouthfeel harkens a bit towards Drie Fonteinen, with touches of quenching dryness remaining secondary to that musty cobweb and wet basement quality so seldom found in fruit lambics, moreso in top-tier gueuzes. The fruit hits up front and at the end, which strikes me as a very excellent quality. Pierre Tilquin has created a fruit lambic so distinct from the traditionally dominant blenders/brewers, and it excels. Superb.

A steady pour into my large Tripel Karmeliet tulip produces a fat-one-finger thick, pale tan colored head; despite the reduced thickness, the head is quite persistent, and leaves a relatively thick, layered lacing on the sides of the glass. The beer is a murky amber color that shows a light read stained, light-gold hue when held up to the light. The nose smells tart and quite fruity at first blush. Musty, woody, lightly spicy, and floral notes also play a role. Specific aromas of light urea, sweet floral notes leaning towards carnations, perhaps a touch of rose, definite floral plum, and even some peppery floral notes add to the blossoming expression found here. Dried wildflowers, dried hay, and a touch of grain like character are found in the long finish.

Quite a bit more sour tasting than the aroma might have suggested; this has a bracing acidity that is mostly lactic in character, but whose complexity seems to be boosted by a fruit derived acidity too. This is quite effervescent, and definitely light bodied, which suggest at a champagne like texture, but this does have more body than a champagne, with a touch of lactic slickness and some touches of residual grain body. The finish is quite dry, definitely acidic, a touch spicy, with a musty phenolic note, and with quite a bit of wood flavors. The floral and fruit character is a bit reduced from the aroma, but still contributes noticeable spicy floral notes, touches of something like carnations, and a general fruitiness that could lean towards floral plum like notes, and perhaps even some tart, astringent, dark berry like notes. The long finish almost has a strawberry note, perhaps it is guava, or papaya, but a definite interesting fruit edge to the flavor. As the beer warms up it gets quite a bit more fruity, and in complex, unexpected ways (tropical).

This is a pretty fantastic Fruit Lambic. The plums contribute more of a general, though quite noticeable, fruitiness rather than being as specific as say a Frambois, or a Kriek, but it still really works quite well; it makes this a bit more Gueuze like in some ways, which is certainly not a bad thing. There is lots of wood, lots of fruit, omnipresent sourness, and a solid funkiness, all of which make for a nicely balanced beer that I am quite enjoying; much better than I expected even, Tilquin is really doing things right.

Pours an red-orangish brown color. Probably a bit too red for a wood stain, but it would be a bright cherry pine, kinda garish, really. No real head. We¬íre in lambic country, so normal rules do not apply, not that I¬ím much of a believe in appearance ratings. The aroma is plum jam on top of mild vinegar and gueuze funk, but the fruit is dominant. The plum smell is on the apricot end of the plum world. It definitely smells like plums, but there¬ís a fair bit of variation within plums. This beer smells more like what is sold as fresh French prunes, around here, rather than the juicier, sweet-tart Santa Rosa plum that I more closely associate with the fruit, though I have no idea what Tilquin actually used, of course. The funk is mildly cheesy with some nice horse blanket tendencies bouncing around (it¬ís been too long since I used "horse blanket" in a review). The taste is light to medium tart with more of that fruit flavor. It¬ís still relatively sweet and a tad lacking in flavor for what I expect from a plum sour, but I don¬ít mean that as a knock. The vinegar tartness is actually pretty restrained, and there¬ís none of that back-of-the-throat burn that many American sours suffer from. Tilquin does a magnificent job balancing the flavors, showing off that quality lambic brewer touch. Carbonation is normal. Mouthfeel is a tad slick with fruitiness. Moderate pucker. I quite enjoyed this beer. It¬ís not a dramatic beer, but it has a lovely fruit flavor and oozes lambic complexity and refinement.
